title: An Attention-Assisted AI Model for Real-Time Underwater Sound Speed Estimation Leveraging Remote Sensing Sea Surface Temperature Data
author: Pengfei Wu (Ocean University of China), Wei Huang (Ocean University of China), Yujie Shi (Ocean University of China), Hao Zhang (Ocean University of China)
background: This research focuses on estimating underwater sound speed profiles in real-time by utilizing machine learning to integrate remote sensing sea surface temperature and historical sound velocity data.
contribution: This paper introduces a self-attention embedded multimodal data fusion convolutional neural network model to solve the challenge of real-time underwater sound speed estimation, achieving improved accuracy and stability over existing methods.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods relied heavily on direct measurements or acoustic field inversion techniques that require extensive data collection and can lag in response time.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves the estimation process by fusing remote sensing data with historical sound profiles using a convolutional neural network with self-attention mechanisms.

key_innovation: Combines local feature extraction with global correlations through a self-attention mechanism, enhancing the model's ability to understand and predict sound speed variations.
real_world_impact: This model provides a method for real-time estimation of underwater sound profiles, potentially improving underwater communication and navigation systems. However, its practical deployment may vary based on environmental conditions.
limitations: The model requirements in terms of data sources and computational resources may limit broader applicability.

new_terms.self-attention: **Self-attention** is a mechanism in neural networks that allows the model to weigh the importance of different parts of the input data when making predictions.
new_terms.sound speed profile (SSP): **Sound speed profile (SSP)** is a vertical distribution of sound speed in water, influenced by factors like temperature, salinity, and pressure.
